name: The Real Harry Potter Online Trivia | For Children | 15 Questions

questions.text: Boggarts, in the Harry Potter books, are creatures that transform into an apparition of your greatest fear. In Northern England, where the boggart legend originated, what were boggarts?
questions.explanation:
Malicious house spirits.

	Boggarts looked something like the house-elves in the books, except that they were hairy. They delighted in the types of acts that Peeves the Poltergeist would find amusing- blowing out candles, spilling food, pinching babies and the like. It was almost impossible to get rid of them- the only cure for a Boggart infestation was moving!

questions.text: Parts of quite a few plants and creatures are mentioned as potion ingredients. Which potion contributor is not real?
questions.explanation:
Flobberworm.

	The boomslang is a deadly African snake. Asphodel and dittany are herbs that have long been used in potions.

questions.text: One of the centaurs that Harry meets in the Forbidden Forest is named Firenze. What is the significance of this name?
questions.correct: It is the name of a city of learning
options: It is the name of a person who wrote about centaurs
It is the name of a famous philosopher
It is the name of a famous alchemist
questions.explanation:
It is the name of a city of learning.

	Firenze is the Italian name for Florence, a city known as a fount of learning and wisdom. As centaurs are very wise creatures, this is an appropriate name.

questions.text: One potion ingredient is the bezoar, supposedly found in the stomach of a goat. Is this  a real item?
questions.explanation:
Yes.

	There is even one wild goat, a species of ibex, known as the "bezoar goat."

questions.text: Harry learns that the Grim, a huge black dog, is an apparition that foretells death. The Grim has been a part of Yorkshire tales for many years. What is it known as in Yorkshire?
questions.explanation:
Barghest.

	All over Great Britain, large black dogs are symbols of impending doom.

questions.text: The grindylow, a water demon, is a part of Yorkshire folklore, like many of the creatures in the Potter series. In the Yorkshire tales, what was the grindylow known for?
questions.explanation:
Eating children.

	It would lurk near shore, grabbing any children that came to the water's edge.

questions.text: The basilisk that Harry faced differed from the mythological portrayal of its kind in several respects. What was one of these differences?
options: Its reaction to a rooster's crow
questions.explanation:
Its size.

	In European and Middle Eastern mythology, the basilisk was a smallish creature.

questions.text: From what literary work is the spider Aragog likely to have derived his name?
questions.explanation:
The Bible.

	While the "ara" portion of the name refers to a spider, Gog and Magog were Biblical giants who were allies of the Devil.

questions.text: Beauxbatons Academy is probably located in France. What does its name mean?
questions.explanation:
Beautiful sticks.

	This may be a reference to wands.

questions.text: Sirius Black is named after what dog-related object?
questions.explanation:
A star.

	Sirius, located in the constellation Canis Major, is also known as the "Dog Star."

questions.text: The pus-filled bubotubers take their name from what deadly disease?
questions.explanation:
Plague.

	Plague victims break out in pus-filled blisters called buboes.

questions.text: Dumbledore's phoenix is named Fawkes. What did the real Fawkes do?
options: Saved many people from a fire
questions.explanation:
Attempted bombing.

	Guy Fawkes attempted to blow up the British House of Parliament in 1605. Guy Fawkes day is still celebrated with fireworks, bonfires and other fire-related activities, appropriate for a phoenix.

questions.text: The caretaker of Hogwarts is named Argus Filch. Why is this name appropriate?
options: Argus liked to spy on others
questions.explanation:
Argus had many eyes.

	Argus was a Greek giant with one hundred eyes.

questions.text: Was there a real Nicolas Flamel?
questions.explanation:
Yes.

	Yes, and just as in the books, he was an alchemist. He lived from 1330-1418, was quite successful in business, and gave generous endowments to public works. There is a street named after him in Paris.

questions.text: Hedwig, Harry's snowy owl, is named after a what?
questions.explanation:
Saint.

	St. Hedwig was female. She lived from 1174-1243 in Germany (then Silesia.) She received sainthood for aiding and comforting victims of every kind of tragedy.
